questions.question: "How can you minimise all views except for the currently selected view in the Eclipse interface?"
questions.answer: "all of these answers"
choices: Press Control-M (Windows) or Command-M (Mac)
Double-click the tab you want to maximise
all of these answers
Click the Maximise button at the top right of the view

questions.question: "What happens when you execute the Run -> Skip all Breakpoints command?"
questions.answer: "All breakpoints will not be fired when debugging and will not cause application execution to suspend"
choices: All breakpoints are deleted
none of these answers
All breakpoints will not be fired when debugging and will not cause application execution to suspend
All breakpoints and bookmarks are disabled

questions.question: "What is not a key part of Eclipse projects and technologies?"
questions.answer: "Java Development Toold (JDT)"
choices: Plug-in Development Environment (PDE)
Eclipse Project
Java Development Toold (JDT)
Eclipse .NET

questions.question: "Which is a valid way to create a code snippet?"
questions.answer: "Right-click the selected code and select Add to Snippets"
choices: Right-click the selected code and select Add to Snippets
Drag the code into the snippets view
Click Source -> Snippets -> Create Snippet
With the code selected, click the + button in the Snippets view

questions.question: "In this image, what does the circled button do?"
questions.answer: "It allows changes from one version of a file to be applied to another version of the file."
choices: It expands the comparison between the two files to include whitespace.
It allows you to delete the line of code to which it is connected.
It allows changes from one version of a file to be applied to another version of the file.
It allows you to merge both lines of code together.

questions.question: "When inserting a snippet containing variables into a source file, how are values for the variable defined?"
questions.answer: "They are automatically highlighted in code."
choices: Eclipse fills them in with a drop-down menu of available optons.
They are automatically highlighted in code.
They are populated using environment variables.
You populate them through a pop-up windows.

questions.question: "How can you create a new Git branch in Eclipse?"
questions.answer: "all of these answers"
choices: all of these answers
Right-click your project in the Package Explorer and select Team -> Switch To -> New Branch
Click File -> New -> Git -> Branch
Click Source -> Team -> Switch To -> New Branch

questions.question: "Why might you use the Open Type button?"
questions.answer: "to search the workbench for a class to open in an editor"
choices: to open a file by its name
to search the workbench for a class to open in an editor
to find a string in a text file
to find all places where a certain type is instantiated

questions.question: "In the JUnit view, what is the value in the parentheses after a previously run unit test?"
questions.answer: "the time it took the test to run"
choices: the number of errors found in the test
the time it took the test to run
the name of the package containing the test class
the test class name

questions.question: "In this image, what does the circled icon in the Problems view do?"
questions.answer: "It opens the Filter menu so you can customise what problems are displayed."
choices: It sends the currently selected problem to another view.
It indents the currently selected problem.
It opens the Filter menu so you can customise what problems are displayed.
It jumps to the currently selected problem in the Editor.

questions.question: "What can you not do in the Expressions view?"
questions.answer: "track the value of a variable throughout the lifetime of the app."
choices: track the value of a variable throughout the lifetime of the app.
change the name of a variable while debugging.
change the value of a final variable while debugging.
track values of variables when they are out of scope.

questions.question: "Your code is highlighted in red when running code coverage. Why is this?"
questions.answer: "No code calls the method."
choices: The code is the cause of a compiler warning.
The method is unused or causes runtime errors.
The code is within an if statement that is always evaluated as true at runtime.
No code calls the method.

questions.question: "When selecting the Synchronise Workspace option for a project, what perspective is opened?"
questions.answer: "Team Synchronising"
choices: Git
Java
Team Synchronising
Remote Synchronise

questions.question: "Which is not a way to check the value of a variable while debugging?"
questions.answer: "Watch the variable in the Expressions view."
choices: Hover ove the variable in the Editor.
Check the Debug view.
Check the Variables view.
Watch the variable in the Expressions view.

questions.question: "How can you configure Eclipse to open a webpage in a browser outside of Eclipse using the Windows (Eclipse) -> Preferences -> General -> Web Browser dialog page?"
questions.answer: "Select Use external web browser, click the New or Search button, add your browser, and then select it in the External web browsers menu."
choices: Select Use external web browser.
Select Add a new browser and select the desired browser in the External web browsers menu.
Select Use external web browser, click the New or Search button, add your browser, and then select it in the External web browsers menu.
Use the Search button to search for an installed web browser.

questions.question: "What view, within the Team component, displays the commits related to a particular project or file?"
questions.answer: "History"
choices: Git Staging
History
Synchronize
Git Repositories

questions.question: "What is included in your wqorkspace folder?"
questions.answer: "a hidden .metadata folder and projects created in the workspace"
choices: a hidden .metadata folder
a hidden .metadata folder and projects imported into the workspace only
only projects imported into the workspace
a hidden .metadata folder and projects created in the workspace

questions.question: "What can you not do in the Variables view?"
questions.answer: "edit the value of a variable while the debugger is running your app"
choices: monitor variables that are outside the scope of the current stack frame
set a breakpoint to track a particular instance
inspect the values of an object's fields
edit the value of a variable while the debugger is running your app

questions.question: "What is not a method stub that Eclipse will create for you in the New JUnit Test Case window?"
questions.answer: "setUpClass()"
choices: tearDown()
setUpClass()
tearDownAfterClass()
setUp()

questions.question: "What does the Problems view show?"
questions.answer: "all of the answers"
choices: all of the answers
warnings and errors
code that does not match your formatting settings
threads containing errors

questions.question: "When switching workspaces, what is preserved?"
questions.answer: "all preferences"
choices: all preferences
none of these answers
the current perspective
preferences for a language (e.g., Java)

questions.question: "How can you set files to save automatically when launching an application?"
questions.answer: "Click Window (Eclipse) -> Preferences -> Run/Debug -> Launching, and then select Save required dirty editors before launching."
choices: Click Window (Eclipse) -> Preferences -> Run/Debug -> Launching, and then select Save required dirty editors before launching.
Click Window (Eclipse) -> Preferences -> Java -> Editor -> Save Actions
Click File -> Save All.
Change the project's run configuration.

questions.question: "Which is _not_ a valid way to create a test class?"
questions.answer: "none of these answers"
choices: In the **Package Explorer**, right-click a class and select **New > JUnit Test Case**.
none of these answers
Create a JUnit Test Case class through the **File** menu.
Create the class manually while in any perspective.

questions.question: "What happens when you double-click a Revision Time in the History view?"
questions.answer: "The select file is opened in the Editor in its state at the time of the revision."
choices: Nothing happens.
The select file is opened in the Editor in its state at the time of the revision.
The revision opens in a **Split Editor** window alongside the current local revision of the file.
A pop-up window showing details about the revision appears.

questions.question: "What is the benefit of using perspectives?"
questions.answer: "to easily switch between different layouts of views in the Workbenchfor specific tasks"
choices: to switch between preferences within a single workspace
to easily switch between different layouts of views in the Workbenchfor specific tasks
to manage the fact that some views work only in certain perspectives
to debug multiple applications at the same time

questions.question: "When viewing an XML file in Eclipse, how can you view the file in a visual hierarchy (as opposed to code alone)?"
choices: You cannot do this in Eclipse.
Select the Editor tab for the XML file and then click the Design tab at the bottom of the editor window.
Double-click the open tab in the Editor.
In the Package Explorer, right-click the file and select Open With > Desgign Editor.

questions.question: "How can you view all the commits for a single file?"
questions.answer: "Right-click the file in the Package Explorer and select Team > Show in History."
choices: Open the commit in the Git Staging view.
Open the commit in the Git Reflog view.
Double-click a commit in the History view.
Right-click the file in the Package Explorer and select Team > Show in History.

questions.question: "In the image below, what does the circled button do?"
choices: It links the Editor and Navigator, causing the Editor to switch to the file selected in the Package Explorer and vice versa.
It expands Libraries when you are in the Java perspective.
It minimizes the left view
It collapses open folders in the Package Explorer view.

questions.question: "Why might you create multiple debug configurations for the same project?"
choices: all of these answers
to debug using a different JRE
to customize environment variables
to customize arguments

questions.question: "You are searching for code using the Search dialog, and no results appear. What is a likely cause?"
choices: all of these answers
The scope of the search is too narrow.
The type of search is not appropriate for the language of the code.
There is a typo in the search parameters.

questions.question: "If you check out a branch in Eclipse and still see the old code, what is one possible problem?"
questions.answer: "Your project is not using source control."
choices: Your project is not using source control.
Your internet connection is down.
Your Git passwordis incorrect.
You need to refresh your project.

questions.question: "What is required to create a Git commit?"
questions.answer: "all of these answers"
choices: all of these answers
a local repository
staged changes
a commit message

questions.question: "What can you do in the Eclipse Split Editor?"
choices: view the Design and Source tabs of one XML file at the same time
drag code from one Editor pane into another
split the editor either horizontally or vertically
all of these answers

questions.question: "Why might you run the Project > Clean command?"
choices: to remedy an issue where the source code seemsaccurate, but Git is indicating a merge conflict
to remedy syntax errors within the source code, causing the project not to build
to discard any existing build state before building the project, which can remedy issues where the source code seems accurate yet fails to build
to recompile only the source code files that have changed since the last build, which can shorten the build time for long-running builds

questions.question: "How can you terminate debugging in the Debug view?"
choices: Right-click an item in the stack trace and select Terminate/Disconnect All.
all of these answers
Right-click your application and select Terminate.
Right-click a thread and select Terminate and Remove.

questions.question: "How do you connect to and debug a remote Java application/server?"
questions.answer: "Create and run a configuration under Run > Debug Configurations > Remote Java Application."
choices: Click Run > Debug As > Remote Application.
You cannot do this in Eclipse.
Create and run a configuration under Run > Debug Configurations > Remote Java Application.
Click Run > External Tools.

questions.question: "What is the purpose of adding TODO in a comment?"
questions.answer: "Comments starting with TODO are listed in the Tasks view."
choices: It reminds you that you have work to do.
Comments starting with TODO are listed in the Tasks view.
It creates automated email reminders of remaining tasks.
Comments starting with TODO are stored in the Task List view.

questions.question: "When an assert fails where can you view the expected value as compared with the actual value?"
questions.answer: "in the Failure Trace section of the JUnit view"
choices: in the Failure Trace section of the JUnit view
in the Debug view
in the console
in the Outline view

questions.question: "You want to use Bugzilla for managing tasks. What is a prerequisite?"
questions.answer: "Install the Bugzilla plug-in."
choices: Select Bugzilla on the list of repositories in the New Task window.
Add Bugzilla as a task repository.
Install the Bugzilla plug-in.
Create a new local task in the Task List.

questions.question: "Which of these is/are listed when searching via the Quick Access search bar?"
questions.answer: "all of these answers"
choices: files in the current workspace
all of these answers
XML attribute values
Java members

questions.question: "After opening a code file, you notice some of the syntax coloring is missing. What is the most likely problem?"
questions.answer: "The perspective you are using is out of date."
choices: The code has an error.
The code is in a language that is too new for Eclipse to support.
The code has the wrong file delimiters.
The perspective you are using is out of date.

questions.question: "When enabled for a specific section, what do the preferences in Java > Editor > Folding control?"
questions.answer: "They cause the section of the class to be collapsed when opened in a new editor."
choices: They cause the section of the class to be collapsed when opened in a new editor.
They cause those members to be placed automatically in a superclass, if present.
They cause class members to be automatically ordered in accordance with the preferences.
They cause the source code to autoformat as it is written.

questions.question: "How can you specify arguments to be passed to an application or virtual machine when it is launched?"
questions.answer: "Click Run > Run Configurations > Arguments."
choices: Click Run > Junit Configurations > Arguments.
Click Run > Run Configurations > Arguments.
Right-click the project and select Arguments.
Click Run > Debug Configurations > Arguments.
